candidates.body:
* See https://github.com/rerun-io/rerun/pull/9816 for more information

To test:
```
pixi run rerun rrd migrate <0.22.x file>
uv run --with rerun-sdk==0.23.1 rerun <migrated file>
```

We should be able to load on 0.23.1, which can't load 0.22.1 (and earlier) files.

candidates.title: Make store aware of full component descriptors

labels.name: 🚜 refactor
labels.description: Change the code, not the functionality

labels.name: exclude from changelog
labels.description: PRs with this won't show up in CHANGELOG.md

candidates.body:
### Related

* Another shaky step towards #6889 

### What

Makes `re_chunk_store` (and more methods of `re_chunk`) fully aware of `ComponentDescriptor` and have most of its operations operate on `CompontentDesriptor` rather than `ComponentName`. 

For this not to ripple out to every corner I had to patch various places, most notably `re_query` and everything relating dataframe queries, to still work with component names meanwhile. Note that some of this might incur a temporary performance cost!

Some callsites have already been fully ported:
* `re_chunk_store_ui`
* `re_time_panel`, bar its `Item::ComponentPath` links which don't understand descriptors yet

Chunkbrowser after - notice that it lists components with full descriptor now
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/91650923-9350-48e1-950c-5794c3c2bb26)

candidates.title: Improve `rerun` crate forwarding, removing need to depend on other `re_*` crates for viewer customization

labels.name: sdk-rust
labels.description: Rust logging API

candidates.body:
### Related

* Split out of https://github.com/rerun-io/rerun/pull/9820
    * and extended from there 

### What

See lengthy title. The `rerun` crate is supposed to be the only crate you ever need, even when doing viewer extensions. However, over time we eroded a bit and in many situations it was necessary to import other crates.
This PR fixes this and tightens the crates that our examples depend on.

candidates.title: Centralize `RedapClient` configuration/initialization/etc

labels.name: exclude from changelog
labels.description: PRs with this won't show up in CHANGELOG.md

labels.name: dataplatform
labels.description: Rerun Data Platform integration

candidates.body:
This is basically my telemetry branch, but without the telemetry.

It refactors the Redap client construction to allow for arbitrary chains of middlewares, and more importantly makes sure that this exact client is used _everywhere_. This will become very important as soon as we introduce more middlewares (including auth -- apparently we've never set up auth here!).

candidates.title: Introduce a DataFusion-backed table widget

labels.name: ui
labels.description: concerns graphical user interface

labels.name: dataplatform
labels.description: Rerun Data Platform integration

candidates.body:
### Related

* part of https://github.com/rerun-io/rerun/issues/9741

### What

This PR introduces `DataFusionTableWidget`, a widget capable of displaying a table in a datafusion session context, along with the necessary changes to use it for partition table display in the redap browser.

Notes:
- The core piece is the `DataFusionAdapter`, which triggers and track completion of datafusion queries (which are async), and uses egui memory to save state across frames.
- A `TableBlueprint` stuff makes an appearance. This eventually leads to the discussion of manipulating them from code, etc.
- The pre-existing `TableConfig` remains. At first sight, it seems that it should be merged with `DataFusionAdapter`, since both construct implement manipulation of the dataframe being displayed. There are good reason to keep them separate though:
  - It makes sense to keep column visibility/order at the RecordBatch/UI level and outside of the (slower) datafusion loop.
  - Eventually, I would like that logic to be implemented directly into `egui_table`, since it is potentially useful for any table user.
- Likewise, there is a small `Columns` helper. This one will definitely be merged with `TableConfig` as soon as the other use of `TableConfig` are replaced by `DataFusionTableWidget` (namely: the in-viewer table).

candidates.title: Remove warning/error on loading .rrd from older Rerun version

labels.name: exclude from changelog
labels.description: PRs with this won't show up in CHANGELOG.md

candidates.body:
It is no longer a problem loading old .rrd files, unless they are pre 0.23.

It _may_ be a problem loading data from a future Rerun version, but we log a warning and try anyway.

candidates.title: Release 0.23.0

labels.name: ⛴ release
labels.description: Related to shipping or publishing

labels.name: exclude from changelog
labels.description: PRs with this won't show up in CHANGELOG.md

candidates.body:
### Next steps
- Test the release
- If this is an 'alpha' release, you can just merge the pull request.
- Otherwise:
  - For any added commits, run the release workflow in 'rc' mode again
  - After testing, _ensure that this PR is mergeable to _, then run the release workflow in 'release' mode
  - Once the final release workflow finishes it will create a GitHub release for you. Then:
    - [ ] Sanity check the build artifacts:
      - [x] pip install: does it install and run?
      - [ ] cargo install of cli tool: does it install and run?
      - [x] C++ SDK zip: does it contain rerun_c for all platforms?
    - [ ] Populate the release with the changelog and a nice header video/picture, check , then click .
    - [ ] Update the [google colab notebooks](https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1R9I7s4o6wydQC_zkybqaSRFTtlEaked_) to install this version and re-execute the notebook.
    - [ ] Update landing's version of the web viewer (@jprochazk)

A few hours after the GitHub release is created,  will create a
[conda feedstock PR](https://github.com/conda-forge/rerun-sdk-feedstock/pulls).
Make sure Jeremy is on top of it!

- [ ] Tests
  - [ ] Windows
  - [ ] Linux
  - [ ] MacOS


### Temp
![output](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/0ca80087-4589-4bb1-b010-c1991478d25d)

candidates.title: rerun_py: adapt the `register` API to the new asynchronous nature of  `register_with_dataset`

labels.name: sdk-python
labels.description: Python logging API

labels.name: exclude from changelog
labels.description: PRs with this won't show up in CHANGELOG.md

labels.name: dataplatform
labels.description: Rerun Data Platform integration

candidates.body:
### Related

* Related to: https://github.com/rerun-io/dataplatform/issues/527
* Follows:
  * https://github.com/rerun-io/rerun/pull/9537
  * https://github.com/rerun-io/dataplatform/pull/543 

### What
In https://github.com/rerun-io/dataplatform/pull/543, we replaced the synchronous register_with_dataset endpoint with an
asynchronous equivalent. The python client, however, expects the
endpoint to be synchronous.

This change is a quick-fix to make the python client block for dataset
registration task completion so that current user should not feel the
difference.

We should improve this in the future by exposing the asynchronous nature
of the endpoint directly to the client.

candidates.title: Format random IDs withour dashes

labels.name: 🧑‍💻 dev experience
labels.description: developer experience (excluding CI)

labels.name: exclude from changelog
labels.description: PRs with this won't show up in CHANGELOG.md

candidates.body:
### Related
* Part of https://github.com/rerun-io/dataplatform/issues/250

### What
We sometimes use a string-formatted UUIDv4 as a random ID. I think it's better we skip the dashes in these cases, so that we can double-click-to-select.

Before: `0840159d-1af9-48fb-8d14-208e388b26ee`
After: `0840159d1af948fb8d14208e388b26ee`

For AppId I also decided to prefix the id with `app_`: `app_0840159d1af948fb8d14208e388b26ee`

It also makes it clear that this is indeed not _always_ a UUID. For instance, our AppId is a custom string, but _somtimes_ a random string (currently generated with a UUID, but that isn't fixed).
